Indonesia Reekspor 18 Kontainer Sampah Ke Australia 4 Bulan Terakhir
01 Nov 2019, 07:55 by ABC
Sejak bulan Juni lalu, Indonesia mengirim balik 18 dari 103 kontainer sampah asal Australia yang masuk ke wilayahnya. Indonesia juga membantah mengalihkan pengiriman sampah terkontaminasi ke negara Asia lainnya seperti yang ditudingkan jaringan aktivis lingkungan dalam laporannya.
Berdasarkan data Direktorat Jenderal Bea dan Cukai Kementerian Keuangan Indonesia (DJBC), selama empat bulan terakhir hingga 30 Oktober 2019, ada 358 kontainer atau peti kemas berisi sampah dari Australia yang masuk ke Indonesia.
Jumlah itu mewakili sekitar 16,3 persen dari total peti kemas sampah yang masuk ke Indonesia dan dihentikan otoritas Bea Cukai melalui 5 pelabuhan di Jawa dan Riau.
Dari jumlah kontainer asal Australia itu, hanya 18 kontainer yang dinyatakan bersih atau terbebas dari kontaminasi limbah B3 (bahan berbahaya dan beracun). Mayoritas sisanya, yakni 237 peti kemas, belum dilengkapi dengan pemberitahuan kepabeanan.
Sementara 103 kontainer lainnya dinyatakan terkontaminasi limbah B3. Dari kontainer yang tercampur ini, baru 18 di antaranya yang sudah dikirim kembali atau di-reekspor ke Australia, sedangkan 85 sisanya masih menunggu proses reekspor.
Pemerintah Indonesia mengatakan, pada prinsipnya, pihak mereka masih bisa menerima impor sampah selama memenuhi kriteria dan spesifikasi terkini yang sudah diatur.
"Karena itu masih bisa menjadi bahan baku untuk industri pengelolaan sampah, industri plastik dan industri kertas. Tetapi kita hanya akan menerima yang memenuhi syarat, itu harus bold (tegas) di disitu," jelas Heru Pambudi, Direktur Jenderal Bea dan Cukai, dalam konferensi pers bersama Kementerian Lingkungan Hidup dan Kehutanan (KLHK) di Jakarta Pusat (31/10/2019).
Untuk memastikan hal itu, sebut Heru, maka Pemerintah Indonesia melalui DJBC, KLHK dan Kementerian Perdagangan melakukan verifikasi. Namun mereka berharap seleksi ketat sampah yang akan diimpor sudah benar-benar terjadi di tahap awal.
"Kita memang berharap bahwa surveyor di negara asal itu sebenarnya sudah bisa menyeleksi sejak dari awal, jadi tidak perlu sampai ke negara Indonesia," kata Heru.
Di sisi lain, tindakan Indonesia mereekspor sampah terkontaminasi mendapar sorotan dari jaringan aktivis lingkungan yakni Nexus3 dan Basel Action Network (BAN).
Dalam keterangan pers-nya pekan lalu, jaringan tersebut menuding Pemerintah Indonesia mengalihkan 43 peti kemas sampah terkontaminasi asal Amerika Serikat ke sejumlah negara Asia lainnya seperti India (38), Korea Selatan (3), Thailand (1) dan Vietnam (1).
"Dengan menggunakan teknik pelacakan pengapalan, Basel Action Network, sebuah group pemantau perdagangan limbah global, menemukan bahwa sebagian besar peti kemas tersebut, alih-alih dikirim balik ke negara asal, malah dialihkan ke negara-negara lain," tulis mereka dalam pernyataan resmi.


Dirjen Bea Cukai serta Kementerian Lingkungan Hidup dan Kehutanan membantah Indonesia alihkan reekspor sampah ke negara Asia lain (31/10/2019). Supplied

Menanggapi tudingan tersebut, Indonesia mengatakan puluhan peti kemas yang disebut BAN memang sedang berada di sejumlah negara Asia.
"Yang ini kan business to business (antar bisnis) dulu reekspor, makanya tidak pakai Konvensi Basel."
"Tapi ini kan lagi pada transit, tapi kalau betul-betul dia transit selama-lamanya di situ bukan di negara asal, baru kita nanti pakai mekanisme Konvensi basel dengan notifikasi resmi, tapi melalui Kemlu (Kementerian Luar Negeri)," jelas Direktur Jenderal Pengelolaan Limbah, Sampah dan Bahan Beracun Berbahaya (PSLB3) KLHK, Rosa Vivien Ratnawati, dalam konferensi pers bersama (31/10/2019).
Vivien menambahkan, pihak importir juga bisa terkena sanksi administratif.
"Si importirnya mau diapain? Importirnya itu, kan ini perilaku, satu bisa dicabut rekomendasinya untuk melakukan impor, itu ada berdasarkan Permendag (Peraturan Menteri Perdagangan) 31 Tahun 2015."
"Dua, untuk pidananya dia bisa dilakukan upaya penegakan hukum pidana."
Dalam Undang-Undang Nomor 32 Tahun 2009 tentang Perlindungan dan Pengelolaan Lingkungan Hidup, setiap pihak yang melakukan pelanggaran terhadap aturan ini akan terkena sanksi pidana minimal 5 tahun penjara dan paling lama 15 tahun.
Sementara untuk denda materi dikenakan paling sedikit Rp 5 Miliar dan paling banyak Rp 15 Miliar.
Saling meragukan klaim
LSM yang bergerak di bidang lingkungan hidup, Ecoton, membantah klaim Pemerintah Indonesia terkait 46 peti kemas yang disebut tengah 'transit' di beberapa negara Asia.
"Temuan BAN menyatakan lain lho."
"Lagipula perlu ada perlu transparansi jalur pengembalian dan perlu keterlibatan pemantauan independen," kata Direktur Eksekutif Ecoton, Prigi Arisandi, kepada ABC.


Temuan sampah terkontaminasi yang masuk lewat Pelabuhan Tanjung Priok September lalu. Supplied

Laporan BAN menemukan hanya 12 dari total 58 kontainer sampah terkontaminasi dari Amerika Serikat yang benar-benar dikembalikan ke negara asalnya. Sementara sisanya justru dikirim ke negara lain dengan 3 perusahaan ekspedisi perkapalan yang berbeda.
Prigi mengaku Ecoton sebagai lembaga yang selama ini mengadukan dan memantau pergerakan sampah terkontaminasi tidak pernah diberi respon tertulis oleh KLHK perihal reekspor sampah-sampah tersebut.
"Belum lagi akses dokumen pengembalian yang tidak terakses," ujarnya.
Prigi juga mencermati tidak adanya pemberian sanksi terhadap importir ataupun eksportir yang melanggar aturan.
"Seharusnya ada pencabutan izin," sebutnya.
Liana Bratasida dari Asosiasi Pulp dan Kertas Indonesia (APKI) menjelaskan kepada ABC perihal tata cara reekspor yang dilakukan anggota-anggotanya.
"Perusahaan hanya bisa reekspor kalau sudah ada persetujuan dari Pemerintah yang dalam hal ini diwakili oleh Bea Cukai."
"Jadi kemudian keluar BL (bill of lading, daftar rinci pengiriman barang via kapal) dan agen supplier dari luar negeri tersebut bisa mengurus pengkapalannya dan di BL disebut kan nama negara penerimanya."
"Bagaimana bisa seenaknya diubah negara asal penerimanya," tanya Liana.
Ia justru meminta berbagai pihak terkait reekspor sampah ini mencari tahu tentang adanya protes dari negara penerima sampah reekspor.
"Ada enggak yang protes ke Indonesia? dicek saja kebenarannya."
Namun ABC menerima keterangan tertulis dari Global Alliance for Incinerator Alternatives (GAIA) India yang menunjukkan keterkejutan mereka terhadap penemuan kontainer sampah terkontaminasi tersebut.
"Di India, kami pikir kami telah melarang impor limbah plastik. Ternyata sekarang kami menemukan banyak yang masuk melalui pintu belakang,"
"Pengiriman dari Indonesia ini harus menjadi subjek penyelidikan internasional," tutur Dharmesh Shah, Koordinator GAIA di India.

text:
Indonesia has exported 18 trash containers to Australia in the past 4 months
Nov 1 2019, 07:55 by ABC
Since last June, Indonesia has sent back 18 of 103 containers of garbage from Australia that have entered its territory. Indonesia also denies transferring contaminated waste shipments to other Asian countries as the network of environmental activists blamed in its report.
Based on data from the Directorate General of Customs and Excise of the Indonesian Ministry of Finance (DJBC), during the last four months until 30 October 2019, there were 358 containers or containers containing rubbish from Australia that entered Indonesia.
That number represents around 16.3 percent of the total garbage containers that enter Indonesia and are stopped by Customs authorities through 5 ports in Java and Riau.
Of the total containers from Australia, only 18 containers were declared clean or free from B3 waste contamination (hazardous and toxic materials). The majority of the rest, namely 237 containers, have not been equipped with customs declarations.
While 103 other containers were declared contaminated by B3 waste. Of these mixed containers, only 18 of them have been sent back or re-exported to Australia, while the remaining 85 are still waiting for the re-export process.
The Indonesian government said that, in principle, they could still accept imports of waste as long as they met the latest set of criteria and specifications.
"Because it can still be a raw material for the waste management industry, the plastic industry and the paper industry. But we will only accept those who meet the requirements, it must be bold there," explained Heru Pambudi, Director General of Customs and Excise, in a conference press release with the Ministry of Environment and Forestry (KLHK) in Central Jakarta (10/31/2019).
To ensure this, said Heru, the Government of Indonesia through the DJBC, KLHK and the Ministry of Trade verified. But they hope that the strict selection of waste to be imported has really taken place at an early stage.
"We really hope that the surveyors in the country of origin have actually been able to select from the beginning, so there is no need to go to the country of Indonesia," Heru said.
On the other hand, Indonesia's actions to re-export contaminated rubbish receive attention from the network of environmental activists, Nexus3 and Basel Action Network (BAN).
In its press statement last week, the network accused the Indonesian Government of diverting 43 containers of contaminated waste from the United States to a number of other Asian countries such as India (38), South Korea (3), Thailand (1) and Vietnam (1).
"Using shipping tracking techniques, the Basel Action Network, a global waste trade monitoring group, found that most of the containers, instead of being sent back to their home countries, were instead transferred to other countries," they wrote in an official statement.


The Director General of Customs and Excise and the Ministry of Environment and Forestry has denied that Indonesia has shifted waste exports to other Asian countries (10/31/2019). Supplied

Responding to these accusations, Indonesia said dozens of containers called BAN were indeed in a number of Asian countries.
"This one is business-to-business (inter-business) before re-export, so don't use the Basel Convention."
"But this is again in transit, but if he really transits forever there and not in the country of origin, then we will use the basel Convention mechanism with official notification, but through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Ministry of Foreign Affairs)," explained the Director General of Management KLHK KLHK, Rosa Vivien Ratnawati, at a joint press conference (10/31/2019).
Vivien added, the importer could also be subjected to administrative sanctions.
"What do the importers want to do? The importers, this is behavior, one can revoke its recommendation to import, it is based on the Minister of Trade Regulation (Regulation of the Minister of Trade) 31 of 2015."
"Two, for his crime he could make criminal law enforcement efforts."
In Law Number 32 of 2009 concerning Environmental Protection and Management, every party who violates this regulation will be subject to criminal sanctions of at least 5 years in prison and a maximum of 15 years.
As for material penalties, a minimum of Rp. 5 billion is imposed and a maximum of Rp. 15 billion.
Doubt each other's claims
The environmental NGO, Ecoton, has denied the Indonesian Government's claims regarding the 46 containers that are being called 'transit' in several Asian countries.
"BAN's findings stated differently."
"Besides, there needs to be transparency in the return path and there needs to be an independent monitoring involvement," Ecoton Executive Director, Prigi Arisandi, told ABC.


The discovery of contaminated waste that entered through the Port of Tanjung Priok last September. Supplied

The BAN report found that only 12 out of a total of 58 contaminated waste containers from the United States were actually returned to their home countries. While the rest were sent to other countries with 3 different shipping companies.
Prigi claimed that Ecoton as an institution that had been complaining and monitoring the movement of contaminated waste had never been given a written response by the Ministry of Environment and Forestry regarding the re-export of such rubbish.
"Not to mention access to returns documents that are not accessed," he said.
Prigi also observes the absence of sanctions against importers or exporters who violate the rules.
"There should be a revocation of permits," he said.
Liana Bratasida from the Indonesian Pulp and Paper Association (APKI) explained to ABC about the re-export procedures carried out by its members.
"Companies can only re-export if there is already an agreement from the Government which in this case is represented by Customs."
"So, then BL (bill of lading, detailed list of shipments via ship) is released and the supplier's agent from abroad can arrange the shipment and in BL the name of the recipient country is called."
"How can the recipient's country of origin be arbitrarily changed," Liana asked.
He actually asked various parties related to the waste export to find out about the protests from the recipient countries of the re-export waste.
"Did anyone protest to Indonesia? Just check the truth."
But ABC received a written statement from India's Global Alliance for Incinerator Alternatives (GAIA) which showed their surprise at the discovery of the contaminated waste container.
"In India, we thought we had banned imports of plastic waste. It turns out that now we find many entering through the back door,"
"This shipment from Indonesia must be the subject of an international investigation," said Dharmesh Shah, GAIA Coordinator in India.
